entries.prompt: Effective demand is best described as:

options.A: desire for a product regardless of ability to pay
options.B: willingness and ability to pay at a given price
options.D: the maximum price firms can charge

entries.rationale: Effective demand includes both willingness and ability to pay at a price.

entries.prompt: A fall in the price of a good, ceteris paribus, causes:

options.C: a movement along the demand curve
options.D: a movement along the supply curve

entries.rationale: Price changes cause movements along the demand curve, not shifts.

entries.prompt: Which would shift demand to the right for coffee?

options.A: A fall in the price of coffee
options.B: A rise in the price of tea (a substitute)
options.C: A fall in the price of sugar (a complement)
options.D: A rise in the price of coffee

entries.rationale: Higher price of a substitute increases demand for coffee.

entries.prompt: If income rises and demand for instant noodles falls, instant noodles are:
entries.rationale: Demand for inferior goods falls as income rises.

entries.prompt: A decrease in input costs will most likely:

options.C: cause a movement along the supply curve

entries.rationale: Lower input costs increase supply, shifting the curve right.

entries.prompt: Explain the difference between a movement along a curve and a shift of the curve in demand or supply.
entries.model_answer: A movement along a curve is caused by a change in the good's own price and changes the quantity demanded or supplied. A shift of the curve is caused by a non-price factor (income, tastes, input costs, technology) and changes demand or supply at every price.
mark_scheme: Defines movement along curve as own-price change
Defines shift as change in non-price determinants
Mentions effect on quantity vs the whole curve

entries.prompt: List four determinants of demand (other than price) and state how each affects the demand curve.
entries.model_answer: Examples include income (right for normal goods, left for inferior goods), prices of substitutes (right when substitutes rise), prices of complements (left when complements rise), tastes/preferences, expectations of future prices, and population. Each determinant shifts the entire demand curve.
mark_scheme: Explains direction of shift for each

entries.prompt: An increase in household income raises demand for restaurant meals. At the same time, a new cooking technology reduces restaurant costs. Use a demand-supply diagram to explain the likely impact on equilibrium price and quantity.
entries.model_answer: Demand shifts right due to higher income, and supply shifts right due to lower costs. Quantity increases for sure. Price effect is ambiguous because both curves shift right; it depends on the relative size of shifts.
mark_scheme: Notes price is ambiguous depending on shift size
